coredata.dc:title: Difunctional carbon quantum dots/g-C3N4 with in-plane electron buffer for intense tetracycline degradation under visible light: Tight adsorption and smooth electron transfer
coredata.dc:creator: Si, Qishi
Guo, Wanqian
Wang, Huazhe
Liu, Banghai
Zheng, Shanshan
Zhao, Qi
Luo, Haichao
Ren, Nanqi
Yu, Tao
coredata.dc:description: In this study, a lateral heterostructures material (LCCN) of carbon quantum dot (CQDs) and carbon nitride (CN) was designed via the thermal polymerization of freeze-dried precursor. The special lateral heterostructures (LHSs) increased the bond length of O–O to fleetly active dissolved oxygen (DO), which exhibits 14-fold increased for tetracycline (TC) visible-light degradation compared to CN. In addition, the electrons of activated DO came from both TC and LCCN, which trapped the oxygen to generate multitudinous superoxide radical (•O2 –), while the hole (h+) showed a negligible role in photocatalytic system. A rapid electron transfer channel was speculated between TC and photocatalyst by experiments and density functional theory. Furthermore, DFT and LC/MS predicted four degradation pathways of TC with the Fukui index (f0), and LCCN exhibited a favorable hinder on various environmental interferences. This work presented a novel perspective for the relationship of pollutant and material in photocatalysis.

Lateral heterostructures (LHSs)
Pollutant and Dissolved oxygen (DO) adsorption
Charge density difference (CDD)
Electron transfer

Enhanced interfacial electron transfer by the interaction of pollutant and LCCN
Degradation pathways of TC, DFT calculation and acute toxicity estimation

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The SEM images of CN (a) and LCCN (b). HRTEM images of CN (c) and LCCN (d) (CQDs marked with red circles). The mapping of C, N and O in CCN (e) and LCCN (f).

(a) Powder XRD patterns and (b) FTIR of CN, CCN and LCCN. (c) Solid-state 13C NMR spectra of CN and LCCN. (d) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of CN and LCCN (the insert picture is pore size distributions).
(a) Survey XPS spectra of CN, CCN and LCCN. The high-resolution C 1s (b) and N 1s (c) XPS spectra of CN, CCN and LCCN. (d) The ratios of N1 / (N2 + N3) relative contents for different types of N 1s.

(a) UV/vis absorption spectra and band gap (insert) of samples. (b) VB XPS spectra of CN, CCN and LCCN. (c) PL spectra, (d) time-resolved transient PL decay, (e) transient photo-current response and (f) EIS spectra of CN, CCN and LCCN.

(a) The absorption capacity of CN, CCN, LCCN and x-LCCN (insert picture) for TC in photocatalytic system. (b) The photodegradation effect and kinetic constant (k) of TC in CN, CCN and LCCN. (c) The TC removal effect of x-LCCN. The degradation effect (d) and kinetic constant (e) of TC by LCCN with different pH in solution. (f) Cycling runs of LCCN for the photodegradation of TC solution. Reaction conditions: [TC] = 20 ppm, [catalyst] = 1 g L−1, initial pH = 7.18, T = 20 °C, Reaction time = 1 h, Pre-adsorption = 30 min.

The degradation constants of common inorganic anions and HA for TC degradation by LCCN. Reaction conditions: [TC] = 20 ppm, [catalyst] = 1 g L−1, initial pH = 7.18, T = 20 °C, Reaction time = 1 h, Pre-adsorption = 30 min [Cl-] = [SO4 2-] = [NO3 -] = [HPO4 2-] = [HCO3 2-] = 0/3.5/7/14 mM, [HA] = 0/5/10/20 mg/L.

(a) The degradation effect of TC by LCCN with various scavengers. (b) Comparison of reaction rate under different quenching conditions for CN, CCN and LCCN. ESR spectra for •OH– (c) and •O2 – (d) in photocatalytic system. (e) The removal amounts of NBT were quantified, and the removal rate of TC for LCCN in photocatalytic process. (f) The change of DO with different catalysts. The adsorption energies and charge density difference (CDD) of O2 molecules and the O–O bond length (l (O–O)) of isolated O2 molecules at the different positions (CN (g), CQDs (h) and LHS (i)) of LCCN. The blue and green areas represent depletion and accumulation of electrons. Reaction conditions: [TC] = 20 ppm, [catalyst] = 1 g L−1, initial pH = 7.18, T = 20 °C, Reaction time = 1 h, Pre-adsorption = 30 min [AO] = [t-butanol] = [p-BQ] = [LAA] = [L-his] = [NaN3] = 5 mM.

(a) The degradation effect of different pollutants by LCCN. (b) ESR spectra of samples, and the different pollutants absorbed LCCN under visible light (c). (d) The transient photocurrent response of the different pollutants absorbed LCCN in visible environment. (e) The absorption energy of TC and LCCN in the vicinity of LHS. (f) The CDD analysis between TC and LCCN. The blue and green areas represent depletion and accumulation of electrons. Reaction conditions: [TC] = [BPA] = [SDZ] = [CIP] = 20 ppm, [catalyst] = 1 g L−1, initial pH = 7.18, T = 20 °C, Reaction time = 1 h, Pre-adsorption = 30 min.
Contour surfaces of Fukui function values of (a) f- for electrophilic attack and (b) f0 for radical attack. (c) The possible pathways of TC by LCCN in photocatalytic system.
Schematic illustration for the possible mechanism of removing TC by LCCN in visible light.

head.ce:title: Difunctional carbon quantum dots/g-C3N4 with in-plane electron buffer for intense tetracycline degradation under visible light: Tight adsorption and smooth electron transfer

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this study, a lateral heterostructures material (LCCN) of carbon quantum dot (CQDs) and carbon nitride (CN) was designed via the thermal polymerization of freeze-dried precursor. The special lateral heterostructures (LHSs) increased the bond length of O–O to fleetly active dissolved oxygen (DO), which exhibits 14-fold increased for tetracycline (TC) visible-light degradation compared to CN. In addition, the electrons of activated DO came from both TC and LCCN, which trapped the oxygen to generate multitudinous superoxide radical (•O2 –), while the hole (h+) showed a negligible role in photocatalytic system. A rapid electron transfer channel was speculated between TC and photocatalyst by experiments and density functional theory. Furthermore, DFT and LC/MS predicted four degradation pathways of TC with the Fukui index (f0), and LCCN exhibited a favorable hinder on various environmental interferences. This work presented a novel perspective for the relationship of pollutant and material in photocatalysis.

ce:section.ce:para: Tetracycline (TC) as a critical antibiotic was listed by WHO, its concentration in environment could reach ug/kg to mg/kg [1,2]. TC was an indispensable antibiotic for animal growth, which reach about the consumption of 6950 tons in China every year [3]. On account of the relatively low rates of metabolism in animal, the TC as unmodified parent compounds were excreted into soil and rivers [4]. The existence of residual TC menaced human's healthy, and caused the potential for resistance selection among pathogens and nonpathogens [5]. Therefore, TC should to be removed quickly and completely by miscellaneous processes [6,7]. For the elimination of antibiotics, the water treatment methods are continuously invented in chemical and biological institution [8–10]. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are effective tools for the degradation of antibiotics, thereinto, photocatalytic is superior in terms of high efficiency, clean energy and sustainable in mild environment [11,12]. Hence, photocatalytic has become one of the primary choices in the AOPs processes.

In the few years, the graphitic carbon nitride (CN) with earth-abundant elements (carbon and nitrogen) has a large attention for the environmental decontamination[13–15]. Nonetheless, CN as a non-metal 2D photocatalyst still had some insufferable shortcomings, involving low surface area, insufficient visible-light absorption, and sluggish charge transport [16]. Now, several optimized strategies have been appeared to promote the photoactivity, including templating, heteroatomic doping and CN based heterojunctions [17–19]. To improve to the activity of CN with non-metal assistant, carbon quantum dots (CQDs) came into the photocatalysis researcher’s vision [20]. Due to the captivating property, the CQDs was an initiator for the idle activity of photocatalysts [21]. The conjugated π structure of CQDs had deposited on CN for the development of photoactivity, by the reducing electrons-holes recombination and increasing the light-absorbed region [22]. Even so, the energy consumption of charges transport between CQDs and CN is too large to be tolerable [23,24]. To solve the excessive energy consumption of charge transport, it is essentially necessary to construct a fast channel between CQDs and CN.

Normally, CN has become a vertical heterostructures (VHSs) with CQDs, also known as Van Der Waals (VDWs) heterostructure. The charge carriers of CN must overcome a large potential barrier (20.95 eV) to reach the CQDs [25]. If so that, the transfer efficiency of photogenerated electrons is not maximized. In order to solve the limitation, the 2D in-plane domains of CQDs and CN are constructed with the lateral heterostructures (LHSs) [16]. The CQDs/CN with LHSs (LCCN) has closer contact between CQDs and CN than the normal CQDs/CN (CCN). In the recent years, the LCCN has a larger attention in the H2 production. Liu et al. reported that LCCN has an excellent charge transport, and the photocarrier diffusion length of LCCN is 5.4 and 1.1 times as compared with that of CN and CCN, and the amount of H2 production exhibits 8.5 hold increased compare with CCN [16]. This study shows that LHSs indeed reduce a lot of the energy consumption of electron transfer, and there will be many electrons reacting with the sacrificial agent.

Currently, the relationship of pollutants and materials has been rarely reported, the photocatalytic performance depends in part on pollutants in water [26,27]. The tight relationship of organic substances and surfaces improved the transport of electrons from pollutants. For the gas reduction, the interaction of gas and surface was crucial role, and the charge distribution was also replacement [28,29]. LCCN as scavenging agent has few studies on the pollutant’s degradation. Hu et al. demonstrated that the in-plane sites of CN/rGO has great absorption for BPA, the absorption energy (Eads) of BPA is maximum around the joints of CN and rGO [30]. However, the mechanism of LHSs on LCCN as active sites is not clear for the photodegradation. Furthermore, the reciprocity of pollutants and LCCN for was ignored on LHSs.

Herein, the LCCN was prepared via the thermal polymerization of urea and bio-CQDs precursor, which induced the better effect on the degradation of TC. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images revealed that CQDs was indeed formed on the CN, and the covalent-bond level contact of CQDs and CN was further verified by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). As compared with the photoelectrochemical properties and TC removal rate of CN, CCN and LCCN, LCCN exhibited efficient photocarrier transport, leading to the distinct enhancement of TC photodegradation. The LHSs construct a micro-regional region to promote the dissolved oxygen (DO) activation, and the absorption of dissolved oxygen (DO) and TC on LCCN. Meanwhile, the possible interaction modes of the pollutant and LCCN were identified by electron spin resonance (ESR), transient photocurrent response and density functional theory. DFT calculations deduced the Fukui indexes of TC and the adsorption energy of DO in water by LCCN. In addition, the toxicity degradation intermediates/products of TC were evaluated through ECOSAR.
All chemical reagents were listed in the Text S1.

Bio-CQDs was prepared from the straw by the hydrothermal method. Straw (4 g) and ethylenediamine (1.34 mL) were dissolved in deionized water (40 mL). Then, the mixed solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated 200 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the brown solution was obtained via the centrifuge, and was purified with a 500-molecular weight dialysis bag. Finally, the bio-CQDs (CQDs) was dried by the freeze dryer, and the producing yield is about 10%.

Typically, urea (3 g) and CQDs (5 mg, 10 mg, 15 mg, 25 mg and 40 mg) were dissolved into 20 mL water, the mixture stirred and adequately dissolved by ultrasound for 3 h. After that, the mixture was directly dried by freeze dryer, and formed a brown precursor. The precursor was calcinated from room temperature to 550 °C with a ramp of 5 °C/min and stabilized for 2 h. The obtained samples were labelled as x-LCCN, where x represents the mass of CQDs, and CN was obtained without CQDs. CCN was fabricated with electrostatic interactions in the reported literature [31].

TC as a goal pollutant, the degradation ability of photocatalysts was explored. In each experiment on TC degradation, LCCN (50 mg) and 20 mg/L TC (50 mL) were firstly stirred 30 min for the adsorbent pretreatment. Subsequently, the TC was removed by photocatalysts in the light-degradation process for 2 h, which is equipped with UV cutoff filters (λ < 420 nm) by a 300 W xenon lamp. The reactive temperatures have been maintained at 20 ± 1 °C, and the pH in solution was adjusted with 0.1 mol HCl/NaOH. The solved transparent fluid was analyzed by High Performance Liquid Chromatograph (HPLC, Waters) and TOF LC/MS (Agilent, USA) in the Text S3.

The pseudo-first order kinetic model was used to describe the kinetic data:
(1)
ln (C 0 /C t ) = kt
where C0 and Ct (mg/L) are the TC concentrations at time 0.5 and t (h), respectively; and k (h−1) is the pseudo-first order rate constant under TC degradation process.

To confirm the role of active species on the removal of TC by the LCCN under visible-light irradiation, some scavengers were drop into the TC solution. Specifically, 5 mM isopropyl alcohol (IPA) (•OH– quenching agent), 5 mM p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) (•O2 – quenching agent), 5 mM ammonium oxalate (AO) (h+ quenching agent), 5 mM L-ascorbic acid (LAA) (•O2 – quenching agent), 5 mM L-histidine (L-his) and 5 mM NaN3 (1O2 quenching agent) put into the solution for quenching active species. The amount of •O2 – was determined by NBT as probe by UV-spectrophotometer method (Text S4). The photoelectrochemical measurement of all samples was narrated in detail (Text S5).

In this study, the Gaussian 09 package (Revision D.01) was employed for the DFT calculations. The building configuration was optimized by B3LYP/ 6-311g(d,p), and the level was used to calculate charge density difference (CDD). Furthermore, aqueous solutions are considered by the solvation SMD model [32]. Adsorption energy (Eads) was determined based on the equation: Eads = Ecomplex – (EA + EB), where Ecomplex refers to the single point energy of adsorption complex, while EA and EB represent the energy of isolated dissolved A and B system, respectively [33]. VMD software was employed for all the drawing throughout the paper. Condensed Fukui function (CFF) was employed to predict the reaction site of TC [26]. Hirshfeld charges obtained with the Multiwfn software were selected for the calculation of CFF values. The two employed forms of CFF are expressed as follows (Eq. (2)):

Contour surfaces of the CFF values were generated by the Gauss View 5.0.8 [32,34].

CN and LCCN were prepared with urea and CQDs by thermal polymerization, which the microcosmic structures were displayed in the SEM and TEM. In the Fig. 1a and b, SEM showed the curled edges of nanosheets about the CN and LCCN, and the microscopic structure of sheets was uniformity with CQDs. The lamellate structures of CN and LCCN were further investigated in TEM to prove the existence of CQDs. In the Fig. 1d, CQDs were appeared on the CN sheets, which is marked with the red circles. TEM mapping showed the various elements of LCCN in Fig. 1f, the distribution of C elements was denser than that of CN in Fig. 1e (The amount of C was increased from 50.4% to 63.8% in Fig. S1). These results determined that CQDs could successfully grow on the CN without the destruction of molecular structure [16,25].

Subsequently, the crystal and chemical composition of above samples were further detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). As shown in Fig. 2a, all the samples had two similar peaks at 13.0° and 27.5°, which are the characteristic peaks of CN with the in-plane units of consecutive heptazine gridding [25,35]. The conjugated structure of CN was accumulated along the c-axis, serve as (100) and (002), respectively [16]. When the addition of CQDs, both the structural phases were still maintained with the decreased intensity, because CQDs hinder the crystallinity of tri-s-triazine units and the stacking in CN [30]. Moreover, compare with CN, the (100) and (002) phases of LCCN were also blue shift upon the increasing amount of CQDs [25,30]. In contrast, the XRD pattern of CCN showed a little change with the surface decoration. It was possible that CQDs break the periodical in-plane structure and infixed the gap of molecular layer in LCCN. Fig. 2b showed the FTIR of the CN, CCN and LCCN, which match well to the characteristic vibration modes of CN. The characteristic signals of -OH, CN heterocycles and triazine units were a few changes with the CQDs, revealing that the stacked structures of CN were not deformed. Therefore, CCN and LCCN have a similar skeleton structure with that of CN [25]. Furthermore, the solid-state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectra of CN and LCCN (Fig. 2c) exhibited analogous patterns, indicating that the tri-striazine-based structures was hardly altered by the integration of CQDs [16]. The BET surface of CN, LCCN were determined in the Fig. 2d, the surface area of LCCN (65.56 m2/g) than that of CN (79.06 m2/g).

To identify the VHSs and LHSs of CQDs and CN, the XPS spectra was displayed in Fig. 3. XPS survey spectra confirm that CN, CCN and LCCN are composed with C, N and a small amount of O in Fig. 3a. The C and O peaks have obviously increased after the addition of CQDs [26,36]. It revealed that the hydroxy-rich CQDs implant successfully into CN, which is consistent with EDS. Subsequently, all elements of the CN, CCN and LCCN were analyzed in XPS spectra. In the Fig. 3b, the C 1s of CN had two important peaks at 284.6 and 288.1 eV, representing CC and N–CN [25]. As the CQDs were added into CN, the deconvolution of C1s had three light peaks at 284.6 eV, 286.3 eV and 288.1 eV. Another C 1s peak is C–OH, suggesting the hydroxyl-rich CQDs were assembled on the CN [26]. The high-resolution N 1s spectra of CN, CCN and LCCN in Fig. 3b could be separated into three peaks, containing 399.1 eV for sp2-hybridized nitrogen (CN–C, N1) in triazine rings, 400.5 eV for bridging nitrogen ((C)3–N, N2 or N3), and 401.6 eV for amino groups with hydrogen (N–H) [16]. Wondrously, the ratio value of N1/N2 + N3 for LCCN was lower than CN and CCN in the Fig. 3d, indicating that more (C)3–N existed into LCCN. The increased (C)3–N proved the coalescence of in-plane heterogeneous with amide bonds, the molecule models of evolution on LCCN were optimized in Fig. S2, and graphite carbon structure could be certified in Raman (Fig. S3).

UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) and Photoluminescence (PL) exhibited the optical and electrical properties of CN, CCN and LCCN in the Fig. 4, speculating the band gap and the charge separation. In the Fig. 4a, the absorption edge of CN and CCN was about 431 nm, the CQDs had difficultly changed the band gap of CN due to the surface doping [36]. However, CQDs and CN were constituted by LHSs, which the absorption edge has a red shift at 460 nm [16]. In the insert picture, the LCCN had a reduced band gap of approximately 2.63 eV which is smaller than CN and CCN. To further investigate the band structure of samples, the VB positions of all samples were measured by the Valence-band XPS. In the Fig. 4b, the VB of LCCN (1.82 eV) was shifted 0.25 eV for CN (2.07 eV) and CCN (2.09 eV), and the energy bands of samples were illustrated in Fig. S4. To get insight into the charge separation with LHSs, the spectroscopic (PL, Time-PL) and photoelectrochemical measurements were studied. In the Fig. 4c, CN showed a strong emission at 460 nm, which the band-to-band recombination of the electrons and holes. CCN and LCCN had weaker peaks for the better inhibition of the electrons and holes recombination, the latter with LHSs was best [16,25]. The rational in-plane structures leaded to remarkably restrain the electron-hole recombination in LCCN. It could be attributed that the localized region between CQDs and CN serve as an electron buffer can promote the charges transport and micro-regional electron delocalization. Moreover, the smaller red-shift of LCCN was observed in PL, due to the new C-N in the interface of CQDs and CN [22,37,38]. The time-resolved PL spectra also confirmed that the enhancement of charge separation for CN, CCN and LCCN. A tri-exponential function fitting was employed to analyze the PL decay curves, and the average PL lifetimes (τ) were calculated by the equation: τ = (A1τ1 2 +A2τ2 2 +A3τ3 2) / (A1τ1 +A2τ2 +A3τ3) and these idiographic indexes were listed in Table S1. LCCN had a slower exponential decay kinetics in Fig. 4d, the electrons lifetime of LCCN (11.30 ns) is longer than CN (4.77 ns) and CCN (5.65 ns). The longer lifetime showed the transport rate of photocarrier, suggesting that the electronic hinder was weakened with LHSs in LCCN [16,25]. Due to the LHSs, the electrical properties of CN were anticipated to be strikingly adjusted by the synergistic effect of CQDs and in-plane structure.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was firstly used to explore the electrical conductivity of CN, CCN and LCCN in the Fig. 4e. Normally, the smaller radius of the Nyquist plots corresponded to the larger electrical conductivity [30]. Consequently, the resistance of electrons transport by LCCN was smaller than that of CN and CCN. Then, the transient photocurrent responses of all samples were showed in the Fig. 4f, the charge density of LCCN was higher than that of CN and CCN, further confirming the efficient separation of hole-electrons in LCCN. Furthermore, the distribution of holes and electrons in CCN and LCCN was predicted by DFT in Fig. S5 [39]. Based on the experimental results and DFT, LCCN exhibited the highest charge separation of holes and electrons with the LHSs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: TC Removal efficiency of various photocatalyst
ce:section.ce:para: TC as targeted pollutant was used to investigate the photocatalytic performance of CN, CCN and LCCN in Fig. 5. Firstly, the dark-adsorption removal of TC was investigated in 60 min by CN, CCN and x-LCCN in Fig. 5a, and the adsorption-desorption equilibrium was arrived at 30 min. The LCCN had better the adsorption ability than CN and CCN, and the insert picture showed LCCN with the suitable amount of CQDs for a good TC adsorption. Due to the adsorption equilibrium before 30 min, the following experiments had 30 min TC absorption in dark by photocatalysts. In the Fig. 5b, due to the flabby photo-activity, the CN presented the lower photocatalytic ability for TC degradation. As CQDs were doped on the CN, the removal efficiency of CCN was minor augment, which the electrons overcame the larger energy barrier to transport to CQDs via the non-covalent bond. Subsequently, LCCN was constructed with the covalent bond, and the energy barrier was reduced for rapid electron transfer. Therefore, the removal rate of TC by LCCN was reached 100% at 60 min, the degradation rate of LCCN (0.0421 min−1) was four times higher than CN (0.003 min−1) and CCN (0.0091 min−1). However, the excess CQDs could lead to the light-shield effect, so the photocatalytic activities of 15-LCCN and 25-LCCN are reduced in Fig. 5c [22]. Optimally, 5-LCCN with highest photocatalytic activity was used for these subsequent tests.

To further investigate the removal effect of TC at the different pH in the water, the TC degradation and zeta potential with different pH were designed. The LCCN in the different pH exerted various charge properties, in the Fig. S6a, the zeta potential of pH = 9 is most negative potential, thus influencing the adsorption of TC on LCCN. Fig. 5d and e demonstrated that the degradation effects of TC by LCCN were increased with the rising pH value, and the reaction rate of pH = 9 (0.085 min−1) was 28.3 times higher than that of pH = 3 (0.003 min−1). This showed that the electrostatic adsorption between TC and CN increased, and adsorption underlies the TC degradation process. According to literature review, the pKa of TC molecule is 3.3, 7.7 and 9.7 respectively, and there are four important molecular structures at different pH values in Fig. S6b. In the Fig. S6c, the TCH- of pH= 8 and pH= 9 was self-degradations, and the breaking effect of TC was 32.8% at pH= 9. Therefore, the removing efficiency of TC was best at pH= 9 due to the self-degradation and light-degradation [40]. For the amount of •O2 - in different pH, the NBT transformation was revealed a in Fig. S6d. The NBT transformation was remarkable at pH= 6–7, the decreased transformation occurred in acid and alkaline conditions. These results indicated that the superoxide was decreased at pH= 3 and pH= 9, so the removing effects of TC depended largely on self-decomposition [41]. Based on the pathways of radical species, the •O2 – would become the H2O2 at the low pH environment, which hinder the degradation of TC [42]. It implied that the •O2 – was possible to a major species, the above guesses would be discussed in the following experiments. After five cycles of experiments, the degradation effect of TC was reduced by 18.4% in Fig. 5f.

Since wastewater and real water commonly exist inorganic anions and cations (Cl–, SO4 2-, NO3 -, HPO4 2-, HCO3 – and HA), it is obligatory to roundly investigate the influence of their presentation on the TC photodegradation [35,42]. The unadjusted pH = 7.18 was employed, and these various ions were added in the TC solution with the concentrations of 3.5 mM, 7 mM and 14 mM [35]. As the Fig. 6 shown, the different amount of Cl–, SO4 2–, NO3 – solution obviously inhibited the photocatalytic degradation of TC. On the other hand, in the presence of HPO4 2-, HCO3 -, the higher concertation of anions gave the best TC removal efficiency. Since the dissolved organics in the TC degradation, and HA gave a negative effect. These results confirm that the different anions and dissolved organic influenced the photocatalytic process, but the individual anions accelerated the TC removal efficiency due to a possible change of pH and oxidizing species [42]. Total organic carbon (TOC) was measured to assess the mineralization of TC by LCCN, resulting the 16.6% of TOC was observed after 1 h in Fig. S7a. In practical application, the degradation effects of TC by LCCN in Songhua River was investigated in Fig. S7b, and the removal effects were a 30% reduction due to the intricate interferences in real river.

In order to recognize the active species in the photocatalytic TC degradation, p-benzoquinone (p-BQ), L-ascorbic acid (LAA), tert-butyl alcohol (t-butanol), ammonium oxalate (AO), L-histidine (L-his) and NaN3 were used as scavengers for superoxide radicals (•O2 –), hydroxyl radicals (•OH–), holes (h+) and singlet oxygens (1O2), respectively [42–44]. As shown in the Fig. 7a, the removal effects of TC (20 ppm) by LCCN were inhibited with the addition of p-BQ and LAA, hinting •O2 – was the main active species for TC degradation. The results were also very consistent with the band structure of LCCN in the Fig. S4, the conduction band potential (−0.81 vs. NHE), which were higher than the basic potential of O2/•O2 – (−0.046 V vs. NHE), suggesting that the photoexcited electrons from CB can be trapped on the O2 to generate the •O2 – [30,45]. However, the •OH–, h+ and 1O2 did not contribute anything to the photocatalytic system for the TC degradation. Although, 1O2 had the ability to destroy TC in Fig. S8, but the HA had not ignored suppression for TC elimination [46]. In the Fig. 7b, the k scavenger/k no scavenger of p-BQ, LAA and Ar were reduced obviously on CN, CCN and LCCN, implying the contribution of •O2 – from DO was major, strangely, the h+ was all not contributed to TC degradation with the suitable potential (1.82 V vs. NHE) [47]. The degradation effects of TC by CN and CCN with different scavengers were measured in Fig. S9.

Specially, ESR spectra was demonstrated the generation of •OH– and •O2 – in the Fig. 7c and d, indicating that is only produce •O2 – in TC degradation in visible light, the signal of •O2 – was increased with the CQDs doping (CCN) and implanting (LCCN) in Fig. 7d. To further quantify the production of •O2 –, NBT was choired as molecular probes in the photocatalytic process [26,48]. In the Fig. 7e, the consumption of NBT was measured, which the amount of •O2 – follows the order LCCN > CCN > CN same as the TC removal rate. The generation of •O2 – depends on the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) in the water. Hence, the quantification of DO in water was measured in Fig. 7f. The DO concentrations were reduced quickly by LCCN, which the consumption of DO decline by LCCN (1.26 mg/L) was higher than CN (0.51 mg/L) and CCN (0.3 mg/L). Therefore, the electrons were fleetly arrived DO to produce the •O2 –, which is attributed to the fast track of electrons. The DO consumption of “LCCN-TC (10 mg/L) (1.56 mg/L)” and “LCCN-TC (20 mg/L) (1.63 mg/L)” groups were much higher than that of “LCCN-water (1.26 mg/L)” in the light, implying that TC as pollutant also contributed electrons for the accelerated decomposition of DO. In the theoretical calculations, the absorbed energies between DO and samples were calculated on different sites by DFT in Fig. 7g, h and i. On the different positions, the Eads index on the LHSs was 0.36 eV which is higher than the Eads around CQDs (0.16 eV) or CN (0.21 eV), indicating the better DO absorption of LHSs. Moreover, the •O2 – formation stems from an electron transfer process: from photocatalyst into the DO. The results indicated that the electrons were transferred to DO, and the best ability to active DO at LHSs. Concurrently, the increased l (O–O) length of 1.43 Å (LHS) compared with that of 1.32 Å (CN) and 1.24 Å (CQDs). This is suggestive of easier molecule oxygen activation on LCCN [49,50]. Base on the experimental and theoretical results, the DO was breezily transformed into the •O2 – by LCCN with LHSs the in this photocatalytic system.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Enhanced interfacial electron transfer by the interaction of pollutant and LCCN
ce:section.ce:para: Furthermore, the LHSs of LCCN as activity site not only could absorb DO in water, but also attracted TC on the surface of LCCN. In the Fig. 8a, these different pollutants were eliminated by LCCN, and the removal rates of Tetracycline (TC), Bisphenol A (BPA), Sulfadiazine (SDZ) and Ciprofloxacin (CIP) also reached 99.5%, 15.7%, 33.4% and 66.5% in 60 min, respectively. As shown Fig. 8b, compared with CN and CCN, LCCN exhibited a significantly stronger EPR signal at g = 2.004 with the higher concentration of unpaired electrons, which is beneficial for the photogeneration of active radical pairs [30,51]. Subsequently, the EPR signals of LCCN with different pollutants were analyzed in visible light. LCCN absorbed various pollutants (TC, BPA, SDZ, CIP) all showed varying degrees of EPR signal improvement in all cases, the EPR signal trends were consistent with the removal effects of different pollutants in Fig. 8a. Furthermore, the pollutants of adsorption by hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions may contribute to the enhancement of the internal electric field, which facilitates the offset of the valence electrons to produce more unpaired electrons [30]. The above results demonstrated that the strengthening interaction between pollutants and LCCN was an important factor for the degradation of pollutants [26,30]. As shown in Fig. 8d, the photocurrent intensities of LCCN with different pollutants were larger than LCCN alone, implying that electrons can be transported from pollutants to catalysts. In the theoretical analysis, the absorption energy of TC and LCCN at different positions were calculated (Fig. S6), and the best absorption energy of 0.71 eV near the LHSs in Fig. 8e. For the charge distribution of TC and LCCN, the three-dimensional CDD area was demonstrated in Fig. 8f. Note that the charge redistribution appeared near the interface of the TC/LCCN. These calculated results suggest that the LCCN part near the interface was positively charged, whereas the TC part near the interface is negatively charged [52]. The potential difference (PD) was appeared between TC/LCCN, which is advantageous for the electron to move from TC to LCCN. Therefore, the LHSs strengthened the interaction between pollutants and LCCN, which provides an efficient pathway for the electrons transfer. The excited electrons of TC were possible moved to the CB of LCCN.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Degradation pathways of TC, DFT calculation and acute toxicity estimation
ce:section.ce:para: LCCN can easily decompose TC into small molecules, the degradation pathways of TC were clarified by the DFT chemical prediction and LC-MS/TOF. The condensed Fukui function values were listed in the Table S2, which f– represents the electrophilic attack corresponding the nonradical oxidation and f0 delegates the radical attack. In the Fig. 9a and b, the related profile surfaces of TC were displayed on the f– and f+, the numbers of atoms in TC molecule were labelled in the Fig. S11. These atoms were marked hold the higher values of f0, including C10, C15, C21, C22, O25, O32, O39 and N41, which were more easily attacked by the radical attack. Combined with the monitored intermediates and Fukui indexes in Fig. 9c and Table S2, the degradation pathways and intermediates of TC in the Fig. 9c, Fig. S12-S14. In the photodegradation, the degradation process of tetracycline mainly includes four steps: hydroxylation, ring formation, demethylation and ring opening. Pathway I, the higher Fukui index of C10, C21, C22, O39, N41, TC was firstly transformed into P1. Then, P2 was degraded from P1 via demethylation or C-N bond cleavage, and P4 was transformed from P5 and P3 by hydroxylation. Subsequently, P3 decomposed into P4, and P5 was transformed from P4 by demethylation [53]. Pathway II, C10, N41 with higher f0 index was easily attacked by •O2 –, TC transformed into P6 and P8 by hydroxylation [53]. P7 was formatted from P6 by ring formation [40]. P8 were decomposed separately into P9 and P10, next P10 degraded into P11 [54]. Finally, some larger intermediates disintegrated different low mineral acids (P12, P13 and P14), and these small molecules was breaking down into H2O and CO2 [40,54,55].

It is necessary to understand the toxicity of TC and intermediates for animals and plants in water during the degradation process [56]. Hence, the toxicity of TC and its intermediates was evaluated by ECOSAR software in Table S3 [57]. According to the prediction by ECOSAR, the different response level of the three organisms to TC and its intermediates was observed, the daphnid was most sensitive one. As Table S3 shown, TC and intermediates have very toxic to daphnid in the terms of chronic toxicity except for P3, P7 and P8. Furthermore, except for P6-P9 and P1, other intermediates were very toxic substances for fish in terms of chronic toxicity. For the algae, only P5, P13 and P14 have very toxicity, other substances have mild toxicity. Base on the above evaluation, the toxicity of intermediates in water has been greatly improved with the TC disintegration. Specially, the fish and daphnid have endured the very toxicity of most intermediates.

Based on the above results, the potential mechanisms of TC degradation by LCCN were cleared in the Fig. 10. First, the optical electrons (eopt –) were quickly motivated to CB due to the LHSs in light irradiation, and the h+ was generated in the VB. However, h+ play an insignificant role on due to the low oxidation potential, so the production of •O2 – from DO was an only radical species in the Fig. 7b [47]. Second, the TC was absorbed around the LHSs on the LCCN, the unpair electrons (e–) of TC were stimulated by light. Due to the synergistic effect of adsorption and light irradiation, a part of lone pair e– from TC transported the CB of LCCN via potential differences [26]. Finally, the e– and eopt – federatively generated more •O2 – from DO, resulting in the better degradation of TC in water.

In the summary, a novel carbon quantum dots (CQDs)/C3N4 composite material (LCCN) with lateral heterostructures (LHSs) was designed via thermal copolymerization between freeze-dried CQDs and urea precursor for TC degradation under visible light irradiation. The LHSs structures efficiently greatly facilitated the light absorption, the charge separation and transport, therefore the photocatalytic activity toward the rate of TC degradation 14-fold increased. Due to the presence of LHSs, the TC could easily absorb on the LCCN and contributed the polarization of charge distribution, resulting in the unpair electrons of TC as the •O2 – producer and the inhibitor of charge recombination. The degradation mechanism indicated that •O2 – as single active species for TC degradation was generated by the organization of photoelectrons and unpair electrons of TC. The active atoms with high Fukui indexes interpreted the hydroxylation, ring forming, demethylation and ring opening under the attack of free radicals. The toxicity of TC was eliminated during the degradation process by ECOSAR prediction. Expect for HPO4 2- and HCO3 -, the coupled system had dissatisfied adaptive capacity for environmental interferences. Hence, this study provided a direction for metal-free photocatalyst with LHSs and some deeper insights into the TC degradation in water.

Qishi Si: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing. Wanqian Guo: Funding acquisition, Supervision. Huazhe Wang: Software, Investigation. Banghai Liu: Formal analysis, Visualization. Shanshan Zheng: Software. Qi Zhao: Data Curation. Haichao Luo: Formal analysis. Nanqi Ren: Supervision, Validation. Tao Yu: Formal analysis.
